bibl.title: Letter from L.M. Fisher to Henry Rose Carter, April 21, 1923

div1.p: Fisher comments on the effects of certain types of algae on mosquito larvae.

div1.head: Letter from L.M. Fisher to Henry Rose Carter, April 21, 1923
div1.opener:
JAMES A. HAYNE, M. D.
Secretary and State Health Officer
L. M. FISHER
Associate Sanitary Engineer
U. S. Public Health Service
In Charge Malaria Co operative Work
N. M. C
Clara
State Board of Health
of South Carolina
DIVISION MALARIA CO-OPERATIVE WORK
Columbia
April 21, 1923
Dr. H. R. Carter
2121 California St., N.W.
Washington, D. C.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
Mr. Arthur has sent me a copy of your notes to him
with reference to the effect of Chara foetida on mos-
quito larvae.

I am more willing to believe that some forms of Algae,
when they break up and liberate the characteristic
oils they contain, will prevent mosquito production
than that bladder wort, for instance, would do by im-
prisoning and destroying the mosquito larvae. In my
work on water supplies I have had occasion to observe
the tremendous potency of Algae oils. A minute quantity
will impart a taste and odor to a very large body of
water. I understand, however, that these oils are not
liberated until after the Algae dies, which usually
occurs in the fall of the year. During the growing
season it might be that Chara would have no effect upon
mosquito production.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, L. M. Fisher.
